job.class: ENGL110: Indigenous and Multicultural Literature in Canada

job.workplace: Digital Humanities Innovation Lab (Simon Fraser University)
Linked Early Modern Drama Online (University of Victoria)
The Map of Early Modern London (University of Victoria)
The Public Humanities Hub (University of British Columbia)
Winnifred Eaton Archive (University of British Columbia)

job.desc: I worked as the main programmer for this project and helped with creating customized TEI-XML schemas and setting up the XML repository for the project.

At The Internet Shakespeare Editions, I helped in testing and writing conversions from a custom markup language to TEI-XML. I also developed workflow packages and tools to help in expedite scholarly encoding practices.

Using four digital humanities projects as case studies, the Endings partnership project attempts to develop workflows and best practices for finishing and archiving digital projects. At Endings, I developed tools and workflows for producing archivable, static projects from long-running projects.

workplace.ref: The Map of Early Modern London

job.supervisor: Martin Holmes and Dr. Janelle Jenstad
job.desc: My work at the The Map of Early Modern London involved working in a variety of programming language and dialects (mostly XML based) to maintain the TEI-XML run website.

job.workplace: Scene Performance Journal, The Internet Shakespeare Editions
job.desc: Reporting to the Coordinating Editor, I liased with contributors, copy-edited reviews of performances of Shakespeare, and worked with XWiki and B2Evo blogging platforms.

job.workplace: The Map of Dostoevsky's St. Petersburg
job.supervisor: Dr. Megan Swift and Martin Holmes

job.desc: At the ISE, I worked added to and correct the ISE's performance database, developed and maintained metadata (both a specialized vocabulary and Dublin Core), and assisted with proofing for editions of Hamlet, Twelfth Night, and King Lear.

job.workplace: The Map of Early Modern London
Linked Early Modern Drama Online (University of Victoria)
The Winnifred Eaton Archive (University of British Columbia)
